title: Great practice
body: I have great confidence in the care I receive from the doctors at this practice, and feel my healthcare treatment and that of my daughter has been exemplary.

title: Fantastic Service
body: I visited Kings college Dental Hospital today for a tooth extraction, as my Wisdom tooth was broken and causing excruciating tooth ache.  Can I pass on my gratitude to all staff from the Receptionists all the way up the dentists who completed the extraction. I was made to feel extremely well looked after. The extraction was completed quickly and as pain free as possible, thanks again to all at the dental hospital , I am no longer suffering from horrific toothache, what a relief!

readBy.name: King's College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Amazing Practice
body: I have recently registered with this practice. I, like other reviews, have found the Doctors, Nurses and reception team to be extremely professional, warm and welcoming. I have had bad experiences with another Doctors practice and this made me anxious to visit the Doctors. I can say with the team at Lawn medical centre i now have a renewed confidence in going to see a Doctor. Thank you all at The Lawn Medical Centre!

title: Dedicated care
body: Our son is on the renal ward and we are so grateful for there great care for him and all his problems due to a septic leg which affected organs

readBy.name: The Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Takes time to explain
body: After a hospital visit my Doctor contacted me and patiently explained the details of the diagnosis and explained everything regarding the way forward. I appreciated the high level communication skills which made everything so much clearer than it had been in hospital.

title: Good experience
body:
I attended today for further tests the staff were wonderful explaining every stage making sure I was comfortable in a very calm and understanding way

I was very impressed with the service

title: Safe brilliant treatment
body: The staff at T&W A&E were wonderful to me. The EPN was careful and thorough. I felt safe at all times and was kept informed at all times. The X ray staff were also very good too. I was nervous about going but am glad I went. Thank you very much

title: There when I really needed them.
body: I recently became quite unwell.  On phoning the surgery, the receptionist took brief details of the problem and said a doctor would be in touch by the end of surgery.  Within 10 mins, the doctor was on the phone and after a brief discussion,  made an appt to see me just 40 mins later.  I ended up having to go to hospital, which he said may well happen. Throught my 4 day stay, Kention Bridge Medical Centre were great with the Doctor calling me daily to see how I was doing.  This great care has continued since with the Doctor calling me in for blood tests and ensuring my journey to recovery continues.  The practice in general I've always found to be helpful and caring including receptionists who do a challenging job.  All are to be commended in carrying on during these unprecedented Covid 19 times.  Thank you so much.  :-))

title: Really good GP and team
body:
I have been really impressed with the care from this great GP practice especially over the last 6 months. 

Really helpful and supportive reception staff - very reassuring and kind when I had a minor issue and got me the right kind of appointment. Nursing team really expert and thoughtful, with careful well-thought-through advice. GPs offering excellent, really comprehensive care and treating me as a whole person. 

This has been a tough time and the surgery has been brilliant. Thank you to each of you for being amazing.

author: StarG
title: My Daughter visiting Children's ED
body:
After having increasing back pain over period of 4 weeks, my daughter and I attended children's ED at QMC one morning in June.  
The Nursing and Medical staff were attentive and professional. They were very thorough in their examinations and were able to administer appropriate pain relief without delay. This was very reassuring particularly for my daughter as she was anxious.  
We were seen initially within 10 minutes of arrival and discharged home within 2 hours.  
I would like to say a big thank you to all the staff that looked after us.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: chronicpainpatient
title: Poor quality nursing and medical care.
body:
Went to the ED because I hadn't passed urine in around 18 hours and was having bad abdominal pain. Was seen straight away in the RAT by a lovely student nurse and EDA. The nurse did a bladder scan and then the battery died. Then once the battery had been replaced the machine couldn't find any urine in my bladder (This was a brand new £5000 piece of equipment). Next, the EDA came to do an ECG, all was going well and then they came back and told me the machine was faulty and was showing abnormalities on the ECG so would had to redo it.  
No medical problems actually occurred up until then.  
Then I was transferred to 'ED 2' - the trusts poor method of separating potential COVID patients and non-COVID patients. In this area (which is where the OOH GP used to be located) there is 8 chairs and a few separated rooms. Of which some of the trolleys don't fit through the door and of which some rooms don't have suctioning. So if a patient was in cardiac arrest then they wouldn't fit through the door into a room.  
When the doctor finally saw me they were nothing but obnoxious, the first thing said to me was accusing me of attending too often, and then took a very poor history. All they asked was how much had I drank today, and then told me to get on the bed and pressed on my stomach. They never asked about any family history of renal problems such as the fact half my family have polycystic kidney disease !  
This Dr then said the nurse would come and take some blood, and I would need to drink loads of water  
Next the nurse came and told me to get on the bed while they took the blood sample, so I said that they have to take it from my hand. Then they asked whether I wanted them to tell me they're doing It or just do it. So I explained that its probably best telling me in case I hit them by accident. They then said I'd better not hit them, and got up and left and then said really loudly to the doctor that I said I would hit the nurse if they tried to take my blood... but not on purpose.  
The the doctor came in and kept telling me they needed the blood and without it wouldn't be able to treat me and would have to stick a tube up to get the urine out. They then asked me why I wouldn't let them or the EDA. take the blood, I explained this wasn't coming across as very caring or competent, and they kept trying to coerce me into letting them take the sample. I then said that I didn't want this person to treat me and that I wanted a different doctor to which they just stood there still trying to get me to give a sample. So I finally just put up with the pain and let them take the sample .  
At no point during this whole time I was in A&E was I offered any sort of painkillers so I had to sit there for 3 - 3 1/2 hours in pain.  
Rang the A&E department to speak to nurse in charge who said the doctor was called and what the EDA was called. Was given the doctor's name but the EDA was unknown because it wasn't recorded. Have spoken to the GMC who said either this isn't the doctors name or they aren't a registered medical practitioner.

readBy.name: Blackpool Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Bad experience with CMHRS
body: I was reffered by A and E and I feel that they had no intention of helping me. My wife had to chase the appointment that’s how serious they took me. I did not like the way the Dr was more interested in asking about others in my house. I did not like the way the Dr hardly spoke to me and addressed my wife. When the Dr asked a question about a period of my life when I was no known to mental health services they responded to me with a sarcastic comment. I did not like the way that I feel completely humiliated by them. I don’t like the way that I can not move on. I don’t like the way I was treated and I am sure it is because of my age and gender. I don’t like the way I have paid tax most of my life and when I need the NHS the most it has no intention of helping me. My GP keeps telling me that I need to be reffered back because I keep hearing voices but I can not go back so I have no support and I don’t know what to do.

readBy.name: Surrey and Borders Partnership NHS Foundation Trust

author: Agape
title: It was chaotic
body:
Went to the Urgent Care Unit recently and the organisation there was very good, proper social distancing. Was the referred to MedOcc and everything seemed okay but then had to return for follow up checks the next day in the morning.  
It was chaotic, people were moving in and out, no social distancing whatsoever, no face masks and that extends to staff.  
At one point about 4 nurses were stood either side of a narrow corridor and as I walked past one of the nurses continued talking loudly to the others- didn't care that aerosols could be hitting me in the face as they were talking. This same nurse wasn't wearing a mask and at one point I saw them talking to an outpatient right in face face- showing no care at all. Am I missing something here?  
It is scary what is going on there.

author: ToraDora
title: Right Medial Malleous Ankle Fracture
body:
I had an accident at work (April 2020), a horse was spooked in the stable and jumped on my leg! I went to The minor injuries unit at Wycombe Hospital 18 hours later ( I wasn’t keen to be anywhere near a hospital due to COVID-19) and the staff there couldn’t have been more helpful....I went straight through to X-ray which showed a fracture, my leg was put in a moon boot and I was in and out in less than an hour.  
I received a follow up call the next day from the Orthopaedic Trauma Coordinator ( Elaine ) explaining that my X-ray had been reviewed and that I would need an operation ...this sent me into a spin but she organised everything for me and was always available to answer any questions / concerns that I had. I had my pre-op assessment at Amersham ( clean of COVID) and the staff I met there were lovely, I had my ORIF operation at The Chiltern Hospital ( clean of COVID) where again my surgeon MR Beattie and his team were all really friendly, helpful and efficient ( i was in and out of there in a matter of hours)Elaine organised for a home visit from the Bucks physio team ( again really helpful and friendly) and sourced a ‘gutter crutch’ for me within 24 hours as I was struggling with the elbow crutch due to the osteoarthritis that I have in my elbow!My after care has been equally straightforward and efficient, I had an X-ray at 6 weeks ( Wycombe X-ray dept) ahead of my appt at a virtual fracture clinic ( phone call with Mr Beattie) which happened bang on my given time!  
The whole experience has been such a positive one ....I have nothing but praise for everyone I have met ( all be it mostly over the phone due to COVID) and in particular for Elaine who held my hand (virtually of course!) literally every step of the way.

readBy.name: Steve Baker's Office, MP for Wycombe

author: MK111
title: Experience
body:
Having worked for NHSG for 38 years this is the first time I have been on the other side as a patient apart from being in the Maternity Hospital when I had my 2 daughters.  
I was referred to the Orthopaedic Service at Woodend  
I was seen by the Consultant in February and had my pre assessment in March.  
The pre assessment clinic is so well run with every aspect covered regarding admission to hospital and what to expect following surgery. I was going in for a Total Hip Replacement and was fully informed what to expect and how my recovery was going to progress .  
Unfortunately due to Covid-19 there was a slight delay prior to my operation but I was kept informed regarding this.  
It has been a very difficult time for all NHSG staff during this period with many staff being redeployed within the Service and the uncertainty of what was going to happen during the current climate.  
I received a call a few days before my planned surgery and I was lucky I was able to attend at such short notice.  
On admission to the Ward I was made to feel very welcome and all staff kept me informed of what to expect.  
I was very lucky that I was only in for 24 hours and during that time all staff ensured I had everything I required.  
This has been a great experience for me and the Orthopaedic Service should be very proud of the Service they provide.  
It is up to me now to continue with the exercises so I can return to Work.

author: KID
title: 50 yrs of not talking to someone
body:
My story is about 50 yrs of not talking to someone about my past experiences.  
I was accused last year of being dishonest and a fraud which all turned out to be untrue but the impact this had on my life was unbelievable it brought out a trauma that had happened to me some 50 yrs ago I was sexually abused by one of my brothers he was also in trouble with the police a lot I saw the inside of most prisons and was terrified by this and vowed i would never ever be like this.  
In them days at first i thought it was the norm to have this sort of abuse but did not understand why my other 2 brothers did not do it to me as i got older the abuse continued but i was too scared to say anything back then in them days i feared that i might be taken away from my family and would never see them again so i just kept my mouth shut the abuse went on for years and only stopped either while he was in prison or he eventually moved out my brother was also involved with domestic violence all his girlfriends and wives were victims of this heartbreaking to watch one of his wives being hit by him he was no brother of mine he was and still is a vile person who unfortunatly is allowed to walk and breathe on this planet but he is now an old man who is on his own.  
About 7 years ago i found out that one of my other brothers had also been abused by my other brother the shock of being told this was awful and as he said for the same reasons as mine he never said anything till now none of his family including his wife had any idea that this had gone on my brothers fear was also that if our dad found out he would probably killed him also the shame of it all.  
so back to the present this shock to think i could be anything like him sent me in to this turmoil of not being able to think not wanting to go out and the thought of work just sent me into this awful panic that i would be arrested and sent to prison.Which i really feared.  
I took the courage god knows how and spoke to my GP he advised to go to inclusion I went to the group therapy then onto a therapist when i told her what had happened she told me that i would need intense counselling because of the trauma so I waited a short time and was given an appointment.  
I met my therapist Amachukwu. I was very unsure how this was going to go we spoke a lot about my trauma and he suggested EMDR Eye movement Desensitisation and Reprocessing .This started 14 weeks ago and with the help support and dedication of my therapist i have come through I have been taught so much by him and how to process things also he has given me the confidence that i so lacked. None of this would have been possible without this service I cannot thank this service enough. I hate to think of where i would be.Anyone who reads this and has any doubt i would say take the plunge even in the group therapies where i must admit i spent most of the time crying you realise you are NOT on your own and thats the first major hurdle to get over.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: ab313
title: Poor Care
body: I have found the Staff at Avenue House are very rude and unprofessional. I feel that if you pull them up on something, they will deflect and victimise the patient, not comfortable with their imcompetence being factually challenged. It feels like staff make assumptions, stigmatise and would not hesitate to throw you under the bus to protect or satisfy their egos. It feels like asking for help from a Narcissist, it feels best to not engage.

author: Mutha
title: Excellent work
body:
Joe from Occupational Therapy and his excellent work  
My elderly friend tripped over a kerb and hurt himself badly, he was whisked off to Lincoln County hospital, we managed a bit of contact on day one at A/E (thanks to Gemma), then we had no direct contact with our friend for 6 more days, this was very troubling for us and not good at all for my friend.  
On day 7 a young man called Joe from OT called me up and arranged a phone call between me and my mate, it was superb and Joe held the phone for him throughout the conversation, and you could feel how much this called had lifted my friends spirits. Joe then arranged for a face meeting phone conversation the next day so there was 3 of us close friends huddled beside a phone talking to our poor old mate, we even managed some laughter. Joe commented on how much this has meant to the our friend and we could sense it too, and it made our day as well.  
Unfortunately for us Joe was going off for 10 days after that but hopefully we will still manage to continue these face to face phone calls because they are invaluable during these restrictions caused by the pandemic. Keep up the good work OT and thanks again to Joe.

author: Hoops McCann
title: Our Brother’s treatment
body:
All.  
We would like to thank all of the teams we met and treated our brother Gerard from 30th May . Gerard was a patient in Ward 18 and was well looked after, although we did encounter issues in getting through to the ward both via the direct number and via switchboard.  
Gerard underwent Surgery with Mr Mukherjee on the 3 June. Mr Mukherjee and his team were first class in explaining the issues and the plans and of course the risk . Mr Mukherjee was honest and helped us to understand everything that was going on . A special mention for attentive and understanding should be given to Staff Nurse Kimberly who looked after us and got us access to see Gerard before the Operation.  
Gerard was transferred to ACCU post operations and was very unwell. The team at that point lead by Dr Lucie were again highly attentive and again very communicative and clarified the seriousness of the situation. In Gerard’s more immediate care his named Nurse Ashley / Ashleigh was brilliant, caring, compassionate and so professional when Gerard came from Post Op. Gerard’s one to one nurse on the night shift was Michelle and it was during this point that Gerard deteriorated again Michelle and Dr Lucie were the ultimate in their caring professionalism . Gerard was able to pass away with dignity and his Final Orders again were completed with such understanding and appropriateness.  
We would like to thank all of the teams who looked after Gerard in what was unusual circumstances due to Covid 19 and they offered us every kindness and respect.  
The Whole Family

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

links.id: incorrect named on email death certificate

author: Noimagination
title: Lack of visitors
body:
What has QUEH done to compensate for the lack of visitors over the last 11 weeks (especially for long term patients)  
My perception as a relative of a long term patient is is not a lot. iPads have been put on wards with no training or system for use. Ward phones remain the often engaged only source of communication. Family are still expected to collect and do washing. Menus appear to be the same limited repetitive poor quality offerings as before. Little stimulation or entertainment has been provided. The cutting of toe and finger nails seems to have been ignored. No dental or optician support has been provided and patients have been left ignored and suffering

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students
Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018
South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

author: Ddstego
title: Shielding during Covid
body: You have made sure my mother in law get sufficient food to last a week and have provided us as carers with PPE.

author: DMN
title: A very high standard of professionalism and good humour.
body:
As a retired nurse with a history of recently diagnosed angina I had reason to suspect I was experiencing a mild heart attack.  
I have e mailed the ambulance station directly praising the two ladies who attended me in the first instance with a very high standard of professionalism and good humour.  
On their advice I was taken to the ED at QEUH.  
There they were extremely thorough and even took a chest x ray. Thankfully the relevant cardiac enzyme was low - which was a huge relief.  
At no point was I worried about Co Vid all staff knew what they doing and followed their professional protocol perfectly.  
I was discharged within three hours with all relevant advice regarding follow up care.  
Very grateful for our NHS staff.

title: Suggested improvements
body:
After telephoning the surgery for a prescription request, I was advised the correct procedure was to visit the surgery website and make an online request via e-mail.
After finding the surgery website, which was easily done as advised by the receptionist, I was confronted with a username and password request, which the website explained as a new user I needed to contact the surgery to request!
This meant telephoning the surgery back and I found myself in a long wait on the telephone before getting through to enable me to make this request! 
- Suggestion: When the surgery explains to a person they need to use the website to make a such requests, I suggest it would be wise and make more sense to ask if the patient is a new user and so issue a username and password if required. This will of course save time for patients and surgery reception and reduce unnecessary telephone calls back to the surgery. 

After making my online rquest, i was unsure if the request was accepted and logged.
- Might it be more user friendly to 'confirm' the request was accepted and logged. This would save unnecessary delays in prescription issues in the event the request had not been logged or accepted for whatever reason, user error or I.T. issue etc.

title: hard working and friendly
body: during the covid lockdown i did not really want to bother the doctor with a simple earache but i did decide for a phone check up. after expaining my problems the doctor made space for me that day to come in. he diagnosed the problem and within 5 days i was back to full health

author: Fan mary
title: Mum taken hospital alone
body:
My mum who is 88 recently had to be taken to hospital with a leg wound the paramedics arrived and assessed her leg and the decision was taken she needed to attend hospital due to covid 19 rules she had to travel alone I was upset she left without me  
She got to the hospital started at major a/e then combined assessment then was moved to A9.  
I must thank this ward for all my mums care and a very special nurse Sharon who went above and beyond in caring for my mum and reassured me a lot.  
Mum was discharged 5 days later and this nurse called me for a few days to make sure mum was getting all the necessary treatment and had not slipped through the net of missing care after hospital discharge.  
This lady is a truly amazing nurse and I will always be grateful of all the reassurance and care for my mum  
Thank you very much Sharon 🌈❤️

readBy.name: Warrington and Halton Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Unhelpful and seemingly ignorant of duty of care
body: Attempted to get a prescription. I was told by reception that there is no service available to unregistered patients as that was the only way to access the computer system. I explained that I was from out of town and asked for advice on what to do. I was told there was nothing. I explained that the practice was under a duty of care to either make an emergency registration or appointment. This was not acknowledged, seemingly either not understood or something the staff are unaware of. I gave all my details including my NHS number and referenced my home practice in Scotland. I requested that the matter be referred to the practice manager and the response came back that I was not a registered patient at this practice and therefore no services are available to unregistered patients. I contacted my local practice and they confirmed that there was a duty of care owed to a visiting patient, so I contacted the Leyton practice again by phone that afternoon to speak to the practice manager but was told this person had gone home. I persisted with my request for advice on what to do. I was told to go elsewhere such as a neighbouring General Practice who might allow walk-ins. I gave my contact details with the request that the Practice Manager, who was expected to be in the next morning, to contact me to discuss the predicament of no service, as I was thinking about making a complaint. Disappointingly I have received no response.

title: Excellent Service
body: Over the years I have been registered with the practice, I have never had cause for complaint and have always had quick and efficient service. I have come to look upon members of the staff as friends.

title: Amazing ward
body:
My wife ,Margaret ,Elliott had 3 visits to Yarty ward from the beginning of 2020 of which the last stay was 3 months during lockdown. Fortunately I was able to spend all that time with her day and night using the ward family suite(Chev). 
All the staff on that ward were amazing all going out there way to make my wife’s journey a little more bearable. Unfortunately we didn’t get the result we wanted and my wife passed away on the 28 May 2020.
I would like to say a big thank you to all the staff,and i mean,all 
the staff the the care and the attention they gave Margaret through her illness. I will never forget you. Thank you.

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust (2)

author: Third child
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: The staff are very good and polite.
body:
Fantastic care I couldn't fault them. My own room and shower and toilet facilities makes me feel better. The staff are very good. They are polite and I would employ them myself.  
Not being able to get visitors I understand why and it is to keep other patients and staff safe. Able to use the internet to connect with family and friends. Keeping myself occupied with my crosswords and books.

title: Turn around
body: Had the unfortate duty of taking a friend due to dementia.i found the place filthy .cupboard door in dining room on its hinges .food stains .dirty walls .cobwebs rubbish on sills

title: Great caring
body: Always felt safe when i was in the hospital. I had very nice nurses and a healthcare assistant who always made sure i was ok.

title: Outstanding service and care
body: 111 assessment was effective and efficient, visual online assessment with GP on call at Worcester Hospital was smooth and efficient, the visual instruction and engagement tool was brilliant.My emergency was around abdomen pain, asses ent made on site by GP on call to refer to pre op assessment unit. Excellent speed and review with necessity for a 53 year old appendectomy made. CoVid precautions outstanding, cleanliness outstanding. Treatment and care from Hca/Nurses/Doctors/Registrar/Consultants/Porters/ Food team/ x ray staff and receptionists simply impeccable/extra mention must go to the exceptional care from year 1,2and 3 placement students across ore op and Beech Wards.Care fir me and dignity for others clearly evident. Pain care and regular assessments made me feel safe and secure. All staff engaged and of high professional standing.I cannot thank everyone enough for there skills in making my stay and operation outcomes good.

author: Frustratedbeyondbelief
title: We have repeatedly been let down.
body:
I am absolutely disgusted in the way my partner has been treated by the Leeds Community Mental Health Team. He has highly complex needs and we have repeatedly been let down, even one stating his needs are not of a mental health nature! He is repeatedly suicidal and has been for many years. The Social Worker is at their wits end and has been incredible throughout.  
All we want is support and care from those who are supposed to provide it when needed. My partner is far from an easy case, that is well documented but to be let down in such a manner is appalling. I'm having to pick up the pieces all the time which I should not have to do alone. I do not want him to suffer. I do not want him to end up doing the unthinkable because of mispractice, unprofessionalism and palming off to pillar and post because I feel they do not want the hassle of dealing with him.  
Cannot believe I am saying this as I have members of family of whom are NHS but I ashamed of our service right now. Particularly the way they are handling this case. I ask what is to be done about this because he needs support and care!!

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Leeds and York NHS Partnership NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Fantastic Practice
body: I've been with Springfield Surgery for 6 years. The doctors have been wonderful in managing my long term health condition and the admin staff go above and beyond to support any query that I've presented to them.

author: Robynjenna1
title: My mother being admitted to hospital
body:
Initially my mother fell out of bed, no balance, GP was great came right away when called although receptionist initially asked was I able to bring my mother to the surgery despite me telling her she could not walk and had not been to the doctors in years.  
My mother was then admitted to the QEUH where she initially was in the ARU unit then as there was no beds in the ward she was meant to go into she was taken to level 11 an ortho elective ward. My mother was diagnosed with bad vertigo however also an old stroke was seen in scan. She gradually felt better could manage to walk to the toilet etc when asked could she go home and come back to see the stroke team she was told no, she would go to the bottom of an outpatient list.  
My mother spent 7 days waiting a stroke team review which took all of 5 minutes, she did not need any care and was in an ortho ward for 7 nights when she could have freed up bed space and spoke to the stroke team when they could see her. I just feel the system should be better, my mother said the nurses were very nice and all medical staff who seen her however she would of felt better at home and it made more sense.

readBy.name: Office of Johann Lamont, MSP for Glasgow Pollok

title: Absolutely AMAZING FROM EVERYONE INVOLVED
body:
I had a serious injury after a fall,firstly our thanks to the ambulance Crewe and paramedics who attended my home,there is no words to describe how grateful we are, the calmness helped my husband in what was a very traumatic experience. My grateful thanks.
A&E again what an amazing team from when I arrived to transfer to Benson ward.
Benson ward well again no word to express my grateful thanks for the care.Nothing was a problem,great team coordination always happy,even in this difficult times,never heard staff moaning always upbeat,this includes housekeeping team.
Finally a mention that infection control was spot on,all proper rules followed to a Tee ,doubt u would get infection here.
Well done to  all Staff and Drs .i am on the mend slowly and from what I’m told surgeons done a great job given the severity of the fall.
Things may well have been so different if it wasn’t for the first responders
One very grateful patient

title: Lovely hospital
body: Attended hospital 9 th June lovely nurse on door sent me to the correct dept.the minute I got there until I left which was about an hour later all staff really kind caring and helpful. The nurse who attended me was a lovely man the x ray dept was quick and also take great care of you. Right up to leaving the hospital all staff helpful and really kind. Got an offer to use the phone all helpful nothing to much for them.

readBy.name: Kent Community Health NHS Foundation Trust

title: Best Surgery in town
body:
Very helpful friendly staff, Drs really caring 
Always helpful!! Staff go extra mile to help.
They even deliver my medication when pharmacy refuses to do so. Prescription lady very helpful caring. Thank you so much

title: Deeply concerned
body: Despite the great intentions and dedication of staff the facilities are not fit for purpose for the large area that this A and E serves due to other department closures. As my family are shielding I had to go to A and E alone. I was advised to go to A and E by 111 at about 3pm with severe abdominal pain and I vomited in the waiting area Almost as soon as I arrived. I waited in tears and in agony but was unable to be helped. Social distancing was not possible in many areas. A few hours later I was moved into a busier area and finally spoke to a nurse. My notes had not been recorded but I was told I would be given pain relief and sent out to the cramped waiting room again. I was left for another 30 minutes before being given pain relief by mouth in the waiting area. I then vomited and collapsed on the floor. I was then moved to a bed and given a drip for my pain relief but the pain was still bad. I was then moved to a quieter area for a scan but the pain was still terrible - about another hour later. Nurses realised my drip was not working and replaced it. Still the pain was bad so I was given another suppository pain relief to help. At 9pm I was told I couldn’t have a scan so I would need to go home and would be called for a scan in the morning and was given pain relief tablets for home. I did not get the call the next day so my husband called and eventually got me a scan appointment as I was in such agony despite pain relief. The scan was done and about an hour later I was sent to Canterbury Hospital to undergo emergency surgery. If I had been sent directly to Canterbury I don’t think I would have had to endure the trauma and pain that I experienced at Ashford. More information is needed about which A and E department to attend - I was given no advice by 111 as they were based in Norfolk. Canterbury is only minor injuries now but I understand now could have been able to deal with my symptoms more successfully than Ashford but I was unaware. The situation at William Harvey is unacceptable at any time but  in the current Covid 19 crisis is wrong and urgent action needs to be taken.

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

title: Very caring
body: I was glad I attended this department at this hospital I was given a kind and caring service thanks to you all goodness knows what would of happened if hadn’t gone there

author: Shuffle Bucket
title: Colposcopy - LLETZ procedure
body:
I arrived in Colposcopy on Tuesday. I was taken in to see Ellen to discuss my procedure, then I was taken to the Procedure Room, where Ellen was the Practitioner who was undertaking my LLETZ Procedure. This was along with the nurses, (Rachel & Janet) who were assisting her, and they had a difficult time, as I have MS and mobility issues but they were fab! .  
They were ALL (Ellen, Rachel & Janet) VERY patient, extremely helpful with my mobility issues and All members were extremely kind, professional and put me at ease. Another fantastic team, who helped me in Colposcopy! ! ! Thank you ALL for your understanding, patience and help which you gave me  
HUGE THANK YOU! ! ! ! 👍😁

title: Says it all
body:
This surgery runs like a factory, all they're concerned about is their statistics, and how quickly they get patients in and out. No regard to their patience wellbeing. I've had years of getting nowhere with these doctors as they don't have time to consider anyone with  complex medical historyand do not take a holistic view. 

Proof is in their list word. 

On changing address I explained my new local surgery is not taking patients currently due to the corona virus Pandemic, yet Oxford terrace have still given me 14 days notice as they're removing me due to the home move out of their area  This is leaving me with no way to get my regular prescription of thyroxine!  That's how much they care about their patience wellbeing.

Thankfully I'm clearly no longer their problem!

title: Very professional
body:
Very compliant with Covid 19 protocols.
Efficient prompt service. Went extra mile with answering extra questions

title: Compassionate and Diligent Care
body:
I would like to express my gratitude for the care and compassionate attention I received from Walm Lane surgery recently.

My GP responded at very short notice to a request for my medical records without which a scheduled operation I was about to undergo might have been canceled. The same goes for the urgency of referral to a specialist leading up the operation and the follow up afterward.

I am so very grateful.

title: Excellent practice
body: I have been a patient of this practice for many years and I experienced excellent care. The service is great even in these extraordinary situation.

author: FS66
title: They have supported us through every up and down
body:
Our daughter has been an inpatient at Claythorn House for almost a year. At first we were clueless and emotionally drained as we didn’t know how to help her with her mental illness. It was made even more difficult as she has a learning disability, autism and epilepsy.  
It has been an emotional rollercoaster for us as a family over the past year and we honestly wouldn’t have gotten through it without the help, care and support of all the fantastic staff at Claythorn House.  
They have supported us through every up and down and have made us see the positives when all we could see was a long dark tunnel ahead. We are hopefully now coming to the end of her time at Claythorn in the next couple of months and getting her ready for the next phase in her life. Without the love and support all the staff have given our daughter, we never would have thought we’d be contemplating her getting well and seeing her happy and smiling again. Her medication has been trial and error over the past year and she’s now settled on Clozapine which is helping with her illness and hallucinations.  
Our sincere thanks and appreciation goes without saying and we can never repay the care that each and every member of staff has shown our daughter. To us they are more than staff and we will miss them all terribly when her time comes for moving on.  
They all know who they are but special thanks to:  
Dr. Smiley, Mhairi, Alison, Mary, Maureen, Steven, Caroline, Angela, Lauren and every single person at Claythorn. Love and best wishes to them all.

title: 'Wonderful Care'
body:
A massive thank you to all the staff at Kings Mill from the wonderful man who helped me by getting and pushing the chair from the car and through sanitisation area, to the reception and assessment team in A & E who were super and began medical treatment to the fabulous teams on Ward 25 (pediatrics). The nurses, doctors, path lab, housekeeping, catering and domestic staff were welcoming and kind, reassuring and so professional and caring in this tricky time. The advise, support and after care was brilliant even a call the next day when we were home to check all was well.
 Thank you for the free car park as that was the last thing on my mind and when I did remember after the relief my daughter was ok. 
Thank you to the nurse who gave me a cup of tea and a sandwich in the early hours of the morning after we were admitted day and the nurse who made up my bed. And most importantly the smiling eyes behind the masks, and the reasurance.

readBy.name: Sherwood Forest Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Frustrated by Communication Issues
body: My mother was admitted to the hospital following a fall last week.  I am not allowed to visit due to Covid 19 situation.  Communication with the Wards has been really difficult - phone ringing with no one picking up, phone call being disconnected by Ward, being given the wrong extension numbers etc.  I know they are busy but there has always been communication issues with this hospital.  All I want to do is ask if staff can send dirty clothes down to Reception so I can collect them when I bring in fresh ones.  Also, Mum's mobile is flat and apparently the charger which was attached to the phone when I sent it in has gone missing.  Again something else which happens regularly.  Goodness knows how often property belonging to relatives of mine has been 'lost' with no recompense.  Wouldn't it be great if there was an email address or some other brief messaging system for the various Wards?!

title: An unpleasant experience. The reality of this…
body:
I was admitted recently for a transient bout of psychosis of and relating to my Hebephrenic Schizophrenia.
I found the staff unhelpful for the reasons listed below:

Rushed off their feet.
Overbearing.
Manipulative.
Judgemental.
Controlling.
Unable and unwilling to get to know the patients indivdually. They read the poorly and inaccurate few paragraphs in your case notes and judge you entirely from that. Not all staff--but most.

Some staff were more or less chilled and nice to be around; especially the young males. But mainly glib tongues and blank apathetic faces.
Needs more staff. Needs kinder staff. Needs better educated staff.
I wanted to leave a cheerful upbeat review but i refuse to lie about this place.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust
Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

title: Seeking Advice Online
body: Today I sought get some advice on fasting and the e-system and line of questions were inappropriate. I could not proceed on the system without stating a problem and as none of the categories met my needs so I put down dietary in the hope I would have a telephone conversation with someone. I then got a text back with all sorts of dietary advice which was not relevant to my circumstances. All I wanted was to talk to a human-being. If you are to promote an online service it needs to be pertinent and useful. I note there is no e-mail address for the surgery and when I tried this lunchtime to get through to the Practice Manager the phone disconnected. This is my first experience of the new surgery and the arrangements need to be looked at with a fresh pair of eyes. I am passionate about healthcare but feel the current arrangements for communication are inadequate.

title: Daphne Ward
body: I had a full hysterectomy with several complications during surgery. All of the staff nurses & sisters on Daphne ward were absolutely amazing & couldn't have done any more for me. I wish I could thank them all personally. Lovely clean ward, ever so friendly staff all round. Couldn't praise the staff any more. Thank you all.

readBy.name: Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great doctors BUT...
body:
Been with this practice over 30 years and have had mostly great medical care. Most of the doctors have been amazing. 
Unfortunately the standards of the receptionists has gone seriously downhill. They are unhelpful, rude and don't seem a bit bothered that their attitude leaves a patient in desperation and despair for days.  They ignore messages and don't care about the consequences, then make out its all the patient's fault when queried.  The receptionists here used to be lovely kind people who were always helpful, what has gone so terribly wrong?  Please don't blame covid 19 or the building works,  this has been going on since before both.
There are other complaints about receptionists on here, but when is something going to be done?

title: amazing care
body:
After testing positive for covid I recently returned home thanks to the absolutely wonderful care of the icu and post icu teams
Just to say Thank You doesn't seem anywhere near 
enough
All the staff who helped me on this sometimes  traumatic experience were just amazing 
always positive, always caring even given the fact the risk they were under for their own health
To be greeted on every occasion with smiling faces behind the masks lifted my spirits and strengthened my own fight to recovery
My family and I will be eternally grateful to them ll

title: Always difficult getting an appointment
body:
Getting an appointment at this surgery has always been difficult and not surprisingly during the Covid-19 pandemic it has not got any better. I have been quoted waiting times of 4 weeks for an appointment during non Covid-19 times and during these Covid-19 times it seems you generally have to be actually dying in order to speak to a GP, seems you get redirected to the practice nurses for any other ailments other than dying.
The other issue with this practice is that there seems to be a high turnover of doctors. There seems to be quite a regular change of faces so you can't be sure the GP you've seen will necessarily even be there for your next visit if you need continuing care. I know that the doctor who takes over your care will fully brief themselves on your needs etc, but it is quite disconcerting to see that level of turnover of staff and one wonders what the reason may be.

title: Unacceptable behaviour
body:
I was told my the centre manager I would receive a call to discuss the medication I was taking and what could be done to start me back on the medication.
I received a text stating the call would be a video link.
I called and asked if it could be through a normal phone call and was told I would receive a call back.
I was left a voicemail as the call was from a no caller I’d and was told it was not possible to receive a phone call it would need to be through video call. (I did ask to be called from a non no caller I’d number and was told that was ok and that was what they would do, be it through text of or call)
Come the day of the video call and instead of a video call I am called through a normal phone call.
There were 2 individuals on the call which I did not agree to.
And not once was the medication mentioned by the doctor.
When I did bring up the medication he changed the conversation to something I did not agree to with the centre manager and something Irrelevant to what I was told the conversation would be in regards to.
I mentioned the medication on more than one occasion.
Instead the doctor decided I should come into the building to speak about the medication.
He insisted there would be three individuals in the room and kept insisting it was standard practice at the centre.
Strangely after insisting on their not being 3 individuals he agreed to 2 individuals being in the room which I guess goes against the standard practice he kept insisting on.
I felt belittled and lied to in regards to what I was told the call would be about, I would also like to mention the doctor was rude and raising his voice when ever I mentioned what I was told the call would be in regards to.

title: Brilliant staff
body: Quickly told where to go, in and out in a couple of hours with an inspection of my injury and an x ray

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent and compassionate care.
body: I had to visit A and E on recommendation of out of hours GP. All the staff (triage clinicians, admin, nurses, radiographer and doctor) were thorough, reassuring and kind.

title: Helpful
body: Thank you for your help regarding my PIP application. I am so glad that I have have doctors here at the surgery who are helpful and couldnt ask for a better gp surgery.

title: Amazing Doctor
body: The Doctor was down to earth and made you feel comfortable. Answered all my questions and was not pushy.

title: AMAZING PRACTICE
body: I would just like to thank all the Staff at the Practice, they have been so kind, making calls to my family to make sure everyone is okay and offering support with shopping and food parcels. The Staff have even dropped off medication for us when the Chemist was not able to. I am so grateful to them, we could not of done without them.

title: Excellent Practise, Doctors, Nurses & Student…
body: We had a very pleasant experience with our surgery recently as my daughter wasn’t well, I called the surgery and the reception staff were very helpful and arranged for the doctor to call and discuss her symptoms, he was very understanding and reassuring and advised us to see the nurse to take some tests, the student nurse at the practice was excellent, she was highly professional and extremely kind, she explained the process very clearly and in calm manner, she made my daughter feel safe and calm under her care, reassuring her not to worry and supporting her through the test. I would highly recommend this practice especially the Doctors, Nurses/Student Nurses and Reception Staff. Thank you ever so much for all your sincere, hard work, dedication and support. Best Wishes.

title: Phone lines
body: It says on your website that the phone line us open until 6.30pm every weekday. I have tried phoning at 15.30 hours but there was a message saying phone line closed. How am I expected to get through to you if your phones are not being answered?

title: Brilliant hospital and staff
body:
Emergency admission with sepsis .Doctors nurses straight onto problem and saved my life thank you hardly seems enough
Exactly two years ago same people saved my wife’s life 
We owe this hospital and their wonderful professional staff everything

readBy.name: Western Sussex Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great practice
body:
This is a great surgery with great skilled doctors and friendly receptionist’s. 
I would highly recommend to anyone.

title: Great pharmacist technician
body: Great pharmacist assistant who really did her best to help us. Prompt and professional, keeping us posted all the way. Thanks for your help for the little one

title: E Consultation
body: Very prompt response to my enquiry - within 24 hrs . Blood test form sent through quickly - Very impressed with the NHS service and St Andrews in particular ! Thanks

title: Very good practise
body: Very efficient practise. I like the way of contact for non urgent things  by email. The GPs have always referred me or sorted out my problem quickly so I am very happy with them. GPs and staff are very approachable and friendly . I am looking forward to when we can use the very handy weight and blood pressure pod again. Genius idea that helps keep you on track and looking after your health.

title: Absolutely horrendous
body:
I had shingles many years ago and as I couldn’t tolerate codeine or morphine I was reluctantly prescribed Methadone
I had my reservations but i did try it and it was an effective method of pain relief. Five years later and after being in a serious car crash and having both knees replaced I still carried on using methadone for pain relief. When the time came to stop methadone I was given the choice to reduce with my GP’s support or to be referred to CGL. After lots of reassurances about CGL being more knowledgeable and offering groups etc I decided to give CGL a try. I work full time as a safeguarding midwife and asked if I could have monthly pick up of my medication as I work all over the country. This was not acceptable but I was allowed to pick it up weekly. 
With the Covid19 I was doing shifts all
over the place and had to isolate
with new parents whose child was on the “at risk” register. I had to take one new born to a foster placement in Bristol and was asked to leave on the Sunday night ready to meet the foster carer and social worker on Monday and to return on the Wednesday. I collected all of the court paperwork and emails etc to confirm the process. I messaged my key worker as my
Weekly script was starting on the Monday and I asked if I could collect my
Script the day before or could i just take one Or two daily dose with me for the Monday and if needed for the Tuesday, I explained to my key worker that I had no choice but to go as I was the only
qualified person to go and speak in court in regards to the possibility of the parents being given a chance to go to an assessment unit to see if they could parent the child. 
After providing all the evidence to my key
Worker I was not allowed to take one dose with me for the Monday. I was not sure how i would feel after missing a dose
and if the court case carried on to the next
day it would therefore be 2 day’s without my meds and as I was giving evidence as a person qualified to give my opinion on the care of the child. 
I asked my employer if I could send another nurse to take my place but I had a reply stating that My contract states my availability to be on call when required and to be able to travel at short notice. I was told that if i didn’t go I would be given a written warning. Yet again I showed my Key Worker all of my correspondence with my employer but I was told that I would have to risk being without my meds for 1 or maybe 2 days as she would not authorise for me to pick up a dose to take with me. 
I am so disappointed at the lack of empathy and the way my key worker appeared to take great delight in saying that I had to either lose my job or lose up
to two doses of my medication. 
Since this time I have had another issue with my pick up date being changed without my knowledge. I will write this incident on a separate review. 
Thank you

title: Fantastic service
body: I was really impressed with the thorough COVID19 procedures and felt very safe and reassured. The treatment I had on my knee made a huge difference and I was amazed at how accurately my problem was identified and treated. I will be back and can highly recommend this very professional service.

title: Wonderful treatment, THANK YOU
body:
I came to the surgery to look into an infection which I had had which had been treated with antibiotics by 111 doctor. While I was there I mentioned that my left ankle was swollen. Doctor thought that this may be due to blood pressure tablets, but then did some measurements and decided to take blood samples which she did there and then. This was at 9.30am, at 4.30pm I had a phone call from the doctor ssaying that they had found evidence of DVT in my left leg. The doctor immediately sent a prescription to my pharmacy and asked me to check that they had them in stock. Also told me that an appointent was booked for Monday at 2pm at Epsom Hospital for a scan on my leg. I attended the scan and was given the results straight away. Yes, I have blood clots in my lower left leg, I am continuing the tablets for the next 3 weeks, then a lower dose for 4 weeks and have today received a follow up appointment for 20th July (to see if the tablets have dissolved the clots). They are also going to do a full body CT scan to check there are no problems elsewhere.
I can only say a HUGE thank you to the doctor who didn't just let it go that it was the blood pressure tablets causing the swelling but thought it through that I had been taking those tablets for several years why would they affect me like this now. 
Obviously I am still very early into the treatment, but if it wasn't for my GP the outcome could be so very different as it wouldn't have been treated at all.
All I can say is THANK YOU for your dedication and perception it is truly appreciated.

title: Initial Contact & Process Management
body: There are some good doctors at the practice who are experienced, competent, thorough and listen to what you are saying. It’s an entirely different experience navigating the frontline. I feel as if I’m preparing to go into battle each time. Sometimes you hit lucky and get someone who is helpful. Often not. I have shed tears of frustration on more than one occasion after the call. I avoid phoning and will email/use ereception  where possible. When I received a text with a link to complete my annual review, I replied to the text with some queries. I have 2 of the conditions listed and the application would only let you select one. I also wanted to know whether the spirometry test included in the review would be picked up at a later date. When I received no response, I emailed the practice - first on 28/04, then chased on 05/05 & 13/05. I’m still waiting for any response - even one saying this email address is currently not being monitored. I am now wanting to find out status of second shielding letters GPs are reportedly sending out as well as get answers to my original queries. Today, I tried ereception but no joy yet. To be fair, I’ve only tried once and it was afternoon. Why does making contact have to be such an unpleasant experience most of the time?

title: Best attention
body: I had to attend Cardiology today to have the procedure Angiogram. From the telephone consultation (due to current situation), the pre-op assessment last week to attending and leaving hospital today the attention and care was first class. Everything was explained, everything was attended to with compassion and skill. Most impressed with the whole team and would like them to know that they made me feel valued and safe. Well done Cardiology

readBy.name: Ashford and St Peter's Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Could not do better
body:
Had to visit emergency and A.C.W ward on 02/06/20
From being screened to leaving ACW I could not have been treated better , everyone was polite sympathetic supportive, I felt that all that could be done was. 
I can't thank your staff enough please pass this on
A J Rowland

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust

title: Fantastic GP support with our baby’s health…
body: We have been very fortunate to have Belgravia surgery GP advise us on our baby’s dermatological issues. Not only they offered informed advice, made sure they found out everything from us and NHS sources regarding the illness,  discussed prescriptions with us to make sure we were comfortable with the treatment, but also made necessary specialist referrals that were swiftly followed up with appointments (under 1 week). This was an especially encouraging and reassuring experience as things moved to online and telephone consulting because of Covid. The GP follow up has been thorough and continues ongoing. It is very helpful to have such proactive support. Also, the admin staff’s support has been exceptional. We are very grateful indeed.

title: Disappointing
body: Hard to get through on the phones to make an appointment and then you also have to wait up to a week just for a telephone consultation. Been going round in circles for weeks with my current issue, seem to be getting nowhere and the GP I have seen most over this issue seems not to care! This same person always makes me feel like I’m being unreasonable by asking for medical treatment/advice. Not sure I will be staying as a patient here much longer.

title: Great Practice
body: Receptionists are very polite and excellent, always get an appointment. Every Dr I meet they are always willing to listen and help me with my ongoing problem and give me all the support I need. Great surgery and amazing staff.

title: Very good communications
body: The telephone response from GP is very helpful. Also the Reception and Telephone staff are positive professional and effective

title: Amazing doctor
body: This is the second phone consultation I’ve had with my doctor at the surgery during covid19 where times are obviously a little uncertain and not as calm - and never in my life have I dealt with a doctor so helpful or kind. Feeling really content with the service provided, I’d recommend this surgery to anyone in the area.

title: Brilliant practice
body: Doctor is fantastic always helped me when I needed to speak with her nurse is really lovely I was very nervous reception staff really make you feel at ease overall great practice definitely much better now with the change in staff

title: Simply the Best
body: I have been attending Airedale since March 2019 and I am looked after as a person and not just a patient.  The service I have received from many has been exceptional.

title: Support through lockdown
body: The support through covid lockdown has been amazing. The team has been updating patients on a weekly basis and personally I have felt it has been a support, reminding that their patients (including myself) we are remembered. The updates include uplifting challenges they have been undertaking (for example learning bsl alphabet). The live streaming of staff also informative.

title: Efficient service
body: Communication is great and clear and even during this difficult period I have had any problems dealt with.

title: superb service
body: I did an e-consultation on June 8th. Recieved a call back from the GP on 9th June and then received the link for a blood test and booked it online on 10th June from a choice of several locations. This is 21st century care. Brilliant.

title: Unhelpful
body: My husband was advised by 111 to visit the primary care unit at Kidderminster hospital due to a blocked ear, inner ear pain, vertigo and feeling very unwell. Upon arriving we were met at the reception by a nurse and a medical receptionist and after explaining the situation and that he had been advised to visit by 111 the nurses response was “well there’s nothing we can do about it here” to which I chipped in and said that he had been advised to have it checked Incase it’s damaged to which she said reluctantly “right okay” and told us to book in. So we moved along the counter to book in with the receptionist, my husband gave his name and date of birth and she was unable to find him on the system, she asked our address and found him under his previous name which has been changed by deed pole, she then proceeded to explain in a rather irritated and passive aggressive manner that you can’t just change your name with the doctors and that you have to let the hospital know separately which neither of us were aware of, I had assumed it was just one system.  None of this is anything major but I feel like it’s unnecessary to visit a centre to receive care and leave feeling annoyed by people’s lack of interpersonal communication skills. I feel that it’s important to address these issues so that something can hopefully be done to train people in positions of care to treat patients with a little more kindness.

title: Caring Practice
body:
A very big thank you to all at Darwen Healthcare for my visit last month (May - for bloods). The HCA drew blood painlessly and reassuringly, and your receptionist was equally reassuring.

As a senior shielding citizen who only leaves home for his complex medical status to be treated, it was so reassuring to get a call from the practice asking if we could rearrange the appointment - or was the time still convenient for me ? It was, and in addition I needed to see a GP. 

The team’s flexibility in fitting in that GP appointment at the same time was very much appreciated by me. 

Not forgetting all the other staff behind the scenes who care for us there - thank you all for creating a space which felt very, very safe.

I feel fortunate indeed in being a patient with such a caring practice.

author: Bluehos
title: Being in hospital during covid19
body:
I was unwell. My kidney and liver were failing. We found out, once I was I and tests. But before ambulance arrived. I stood up dizziness fell over. Trapping foot under sofa corner. Causing my leg to explode. But the excellent surgeons. At Ninewells Hospital. (Steven) and his team. Rebuild my foot and leg. That was 60 day's ago. And still in. Ward 10 side room 4. Nurse's (senior Charge nurse Craig). And his team have looked after me so so well. Even when my mental health was not good. I was allowed to have my wife. With mask & PPE. In to see me before me second operation because I was so scared I may have lost my leg.  
In my opinion the Doctors & staff could do nothing more. For me as they went above&beyond to make my stay here as comfortable as they could possibly make it. First Class

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: kjd
title: Admission during the Covid-19 period
body:
I cannot fault the care that is give to my husband, last year he was in the ARI for cancer treatment for 3 months and received fantastic care and follow up. Today he has had to be admitted again this time as an emergency. He is disorientated and does not know where he is, where he lives etc. He was assessed in A and E and treated with great care, put on fluids and antibiotics.  
This I cannot fault. He was then transferred to ward 110, I phone to see how he is and for an update to be told that the nurse looking after him would come to the phone. I am put on hold. I get a ringing tone which goes on for 8/9 mins and then cut off. I phone back and the phones rings for 5mins no answer, then I ring again this time it rings for 6mins the again I phone and it rings for another 5/6 mins. Finally on ringing again I get a brief answer I explain whats happened and get told we in middle of handover call again in around a half hour or so.  
I know nurses are very busy and they do a great job especially now, but now is a very worry time for next of kin when their loved one is admitted and they are alone and you cannot be with them. All I need to know is that he is settled and ok. Maybe instead of that brief answer It may have been nice to say sorry we in hand over I know you worried I will get his nurse to call you afterwards. It took so long to get through to get the response I did. Maybe I am over sensitive but he is under shielding, over 70, diabetic and has cancer. I am so worried about him and need to be with him and can't.

author: People Pleaser
title: I'm so glad I phoned
body: I phoned Breathing Space around 8. 24pm and spoke with Charlie because I was in real distress. I can't fault the level of support he gave me - he was calm, patient, signposted me to services and even made me laugh. I felt so much better and calmer after speaking with him and he is a total asset to the team. I'm so glad I phoned.

readBy.name: Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

author: Second time
title: Excellent care received and as quickly as possible
body: second visit to children's emergency department during this pandemic due to my daughter dislocating her knee. Excellent care received and they tried to help her as quickly as possible as they recognised from the start that she is a shielding patient. This second visit I would like to give a specific mention to nurse georgina and paramedics Bradley and Euan who were all amazing

readBy.name: London North West University Healthcare NHS Trust

author: Addict
title: Addiction
body:
I have used different drugs in a variety of ways since I was 18, over the years my life escalated out of control 4 years ago my 5th child past away at 3m old and my life spiralled out of control ( not that I was really in control of it before) my other children were removed from my care, I became suicidal (attempting but never succeeded) and lost any care in the world, my domestic violence partner was all I had left.  
I was introduced to the recovery partnership where at the beginning I just was going to tick the boxes using others urine to provide clean samples. I was given the opportunity in court to join the family drugs and alcohol court (fdac) I didn't want to stop using it was the only way I new how to cope but I wanted my kids back so I signed up. I was under so much stress trying to say what I thought people wanted to hear, act and look like I was clean and arrange my sons funeral 6m after he died due to complications there was delays, this left me exhausted and run down and I'd started to have enough I didn't want to continue.  
I didn't want to use at my sons funeral so I did my first day without using, then several and managed to be clean to say goodbye (still being watched by social, schools and what felt like everyone). A few days later I fell ill with what I thought was the flu, doctors thought appendix, by time I got to a and e I just collapsed I woke up in resus with them trying to find veins, my body shutting down from sepsis, my ex partner on phone asking why in hospital ( no one new I was there) no contact with kids, no parents feeling all alone. I spent just over a week in hospital and as soon has I got out (still week) I used. Something had changed and It wasn't the same, I didn't want to do this anymore so why could I not stop?  
This is the first time I got honest with workers and said I can't stop, I began to listen and try new things, change who I hung around with and to be honest with how I was feeling, I couldn't ignore what was going on in my life. I had court for kids, court for driving under influence, court for child neglect. I was fighting my ex after he raped me and dealing with grief and my extremely poor mental health. I really started to try and over Christmas when everything had shut down I attended my first fellowship meeting because I did not want to use on what would of been my sons 1st birthday but new I couldn't do it alone, this was the first time I had met so many people that got my obsessions to use, my selfish behaviours and could identify with where I was at, the first time I saw hope if they can change then so could I.  
I got days, months I managed life events clean I never thought was possible (anniversary, crown Court) I attended my drugs key workers every 2-3 days for tests (swabs) I wanted to prove I was clean, hair strand tests I was creating new friends, positive changes and increased contact. I started to change I started to understand the difference between love and parenting I always loved my kids justifying my using with they go school, fed roof over head but I wasn't there presently I wasn't there emotionally.  
I gained knowledge and skills I went on courses and continued to work on myself. A year and 4m after the children where removed from my care they started to rehabilitate my children back here with one night, weekends until they where all back in my care. This was difficult they had a routine I had to adapt to and knowing I had so much to prove to them, to me but to everyone watching. My kids where on a interim care order for over a year I had to fight to get it reduced to supervision order mainly due to my eldest daughter having behaviour difficulties and issues outside the household but I felt my past was constantly used against me.  
By this point I had started volunteering first for a mental health campaign it takes balls to talk, the recovery partnership in the needle exchange and winter night shelter, I learnt early in recovery I only keep what I have by giving it away, like those who helped me and showed me the way early in my recovery. I loved working with people and went on to work with cgl (change grow live) and becoming a director of a organisation I helped establish to help those who are rough sleeping or have complex needs, we work with organisations to break down the barriers to services are sit has experts by experience for the local authority. We have won awards as the arc and I also won the health and wellbeing award for the volunteer work with cgl.  
Today I still work with social services around my daughters needs (rather then against them) my children have a upbringing where I am the best parent I can be(present not perfect) am still clean and in recovery, still working on myself has this is still new compared to the life I spent using. I still have to deal with life on life's terms and the challenges that brings but today I'm content with life. I am grateful for what I have today and how lucky I am to have this life I have lost friends to the disease of addiction and work with individuals who are still in the chaos of what addiction brings.  
I'm grateful for my keyworker Kam now at cgl and supervisor Steve. Chris my volunteer Co ordinator who pushed me to be the best I could be. To fdac for teaching me how to be a mum again and to enjoy my amazing children, to all the organisations like crasac, mind, cruise to name a few that I was a client of along my journey, To my sponsor and friends in recovery and to all those I have met along the way good and bad everyone played a part in my journey to where I am today and I thank them all

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
University of Stirling, Faculty of Social Sciences

author: LooLoo
title: Derby Childrens A&E
body: My young son has attended the department 3 times last week with an eye problem. Despite current distancing and use of masks the staff made each visit relaxed and friendly and he was not phased in any way. Thank you for making our experience a positive one

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust

author: mckd
title: Its been a hard 12 month but I'm almost there
body: my treatment in Ward 27 Bradford Royal Infirmary was absolutely brilliant I had a trimalleolar fracture of the ankle 2 plates and 13 screws. 5 hour operation. Mr Sam was brilliant. all the team on that ward were great nothing was too much trouble especially when I needed the toilet as I couldn't walk and they would wheel me to the loo. Instead of me using a horrible comode. The healthcare assistant girls were really good to me. Its been a hard 12 month but I'm almost there. Thank you all for looking after me. x

readBy.name: NHS Bradford District and Craven CCG
Bradford Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Juniper22
title: Unhappy with Postnatal Care
body:
I had an elective c-section and sterilisation in January. It was my 4th baby and 2nd caesarean. The birth went well, I couldn’t fault the staff in theatre and recovery, they made me feel at ease and were lovely and supportive throughout.  
I then got transferred to Wheal Fortune ward for postnatal care. Within a couple of hours of being on the ward I was in quite a lot of pain. I asked the midwife looking after me for more analgesia and was given paracetamol. Throughout my stay on the ward anything stronger than paracetamol or ibuprofen was greatly discouraged and I was made to feel awful for asking for anything else. I was told that I would pass the drug to my baby through my breast milk and that it would have a detrimental effect on her. Needless to say I had a very uncomfortable and difficult night.  
The next morning my baby was found to have a heart murmur and we were ushered up to Neonatal for an echocardiogram. I walked to the lifts and then on to the examination room with nothing more than paracetamol cover less than 24 hours after major abdominal surgery. Once there I had to be given a chair and a drink, I thought I was going to pass out with the pain. When I eventually arrived back at the ward, I asked for more pain relief and was told that I wasn’t due any paracetamol yet. I burst into tears and was thankfully given dihydrocodeine to settle the pain.  
The doctor that spoke to me before my discharge a few hours later asked how my pain was and I told him that it had been almost unbearable due to a lack of pain relief. He seemed shocked that I hadn’t been given stronger analgesia regularly. I was in an incredible amount of pain in those first 24 hours and whilst I understand the risks of dihydrocodeine when nursing, I feel I should have been allowed to make an informed choice about whether to take it or not; I think it’s wrong that I was made to feel so bad about needing it and almost too afraid to ask for it.  
My baby was given an orange hat to wear immediately after birth which represented a need for support. It was explained to me that this need was due to me having had a c-section and wanting to breastfeed when I had been unable to feed my other children for various reasons. I was assured by my community midwife prior to the birth that the staff on the postnatal ward would support me with nursing my daughter and so I was pleased when she was given this hat as it meant that they would have a visual aid to make them aware of my need for help.  
However, not one member of staff throughout my stay on the ward asked if I needed help, if I knew what I was doing or if I needed information about positioning, latching, feeding cues or frequency of feeding etc. I was left to get on with it completely on my own. I rang the bell several times during my stay to ask for assistance but the staff always took so long to respond that I would try to get my baby feeding on my own. When they did arrive I would ask if my baby was latched correctly and each time the midwife or MSW that came had a quick look, said yes and then swiftly left. All apart from one midwife who proceeded to manhandle my baby away from my breast without any warning. She shoved her under my gown and said ‘she needs more skin-to-skin time’ and then she left. My husband and I were both quite shocked that she would grab our baby in this manner without gaining consent or even explaining what she was about to do.  
No further advice was given so after a period of skin-to-skin I just struggled on with the next feed, no further forward in knowing what I was doing. I didn’t know how to latch a baby on to the breast and didn’t feel like I was doing it right at all but no one listened to my concerns or offered any help. When I was discharged the next day, I left the hospital feeling very sore and disappointed in the lack of support I had received.  
Not all of the staff but certainly the majority seemed to show a ‘no-nonsense attitude’ and when you’re in pain and feeling vulnerable after just having had a baby, this can come across as abrupt and really quite aggressive. My catheter hadn’t been draining well overnight and the midwife was monitoring it. She encouraged me to drink plenty of fluids which I made sure I did. However, in the morning when the MSW came to work out my fluid balance she took one look at the catheter bag and then told me off for not drinking enough. I told her about the numerous jugs of water I’d had to drink and that the midwife was aware of the situation but she continued to speak to me very rudely, practically saying that I was lying about the drinks I’d had. As a medical professional myself, I know the importance of fluid intake to decrease the risk of blockages and infections and help with the patency of the catheter. In my role I often have to encourage people to increase their fluid intake for these reasons but I have never once done it in a way so belittling to the patient. I do feel that the staff need to go back to basics when it comes to giving care. A little bit of kindness or compassion would have gone a long way in improving my post-birth experience.  
I feel that my daughter’s birth at RCH was a positive experience but it was unfortunately spoiled by the lack of care I received postnatally on Wheal Fortune ward. The lack of pain relief, the lack of breastfeeding support and the poor attitude of staff made this a difficult and unpleasant ordeal that I am glad I will not be repeating.

readBy.name: Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

author: Wee eck
title: Covid screening testing for appointment
body: Test was extremely easy, walked through screen, asked pertinent questions re-laying to health and potential contact with anyone who may have been in contact with Covid19. Unobtrusive and safe.
